articles.headline: Rouhani, Blunt and Charming, Pitches a Moderate Iran
articles.snippet: Amid his fervent diplomatic theater this week, it was at times hard to tell whether Iran’s president, Hassan Rouhani, was a genuinely transformative leader.
articles.abstract: Amid his fervent diplomatic theater this week, it was at times hard to tell whether Iran’s president, Hassan Rouhani, was a genuinely transformative leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Descending on New York this week in a Shiite cleric’s traditional fine wool robes, Iran’s president, Hassan Rouhani, turned himself into a high-speed salesman offering a flurry of speeches, tweets, televised interviews and carefully curated private meetings.

articles.headline: Chrysler’s Owners Are Racing for the Cliff
articles.snippet: The preliminary prospectus filed by the automaker suggests that the company’s chief executive is willing to go to extremes to scuttle its proposed I.P.O.
articles.abstract: The preliminary prospectus filed by the automaker suggests that the company’s chief executive is willing to go to extremes to scuttle its proposed I.P.O.
articles.lead_paragraph: What do you call the man who is trying to sabotage Chrysler’s initial public offering by threatening to harm the company, perhaps fatally, if the offering is completed?

articles.headline: Companies Admit They Fixed Prices of Car Parts
articles.snippet: The companies, all based in Japan, agreed to pay $740 million in fines on federal charges of fixing prices on parts like radiators sold to automakers in the United States.
articles.abstract: The companies, all based in Japan, agreed to pay $740 million in fines on federal charges of fixing prices on parts like radiators sold to automakers in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an expanding global antitrust investigation, nine Japanese automotive suppliers, along with two former executives, have agreed to plead guilty to conspiracy and pay more than $740 million in criminal fines for fixing the price of auto parts sold in the United States and abroad, the Justice Department said Thursday.

articles.headline: A Proposal to Freeze Pensions in Detroit
articles.snippet: Detroit’s emergency manager wants to freeze the city’s pension system for public workers, in light of evidence it was operated in an unsound manner for many years, contributing to the city’s financial downfall.
articles.abstract: Detroit’s emergency manager wants to freeze the city’s pension system for public workers, in light of evidence it was operated in an unsound manner for many years, contributing to the city’s financial downfall.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:42 p.m. | Detroit’s emergency manager wants to freeze the city’s pension system for public workers in light of mounting evidence that it was operated in an unsound manner for many years, contributing to the city’s downfall.

articles.headline: With Tastes Growing Healthier, McDonald’s Aims to Adapt Its Menu
articles.snippet: The fast-food chain said it would increase its offerings of fruits and vegetables and promote more nutritional options to children.
articles.abstract: The fast-food chain said it would increase its offerings of fruits and vegetables and promote more nutritional options to children.
articles.lead_paragraph: Under pressure to provide healthier meals, McDonald’s announced on Thursday that it would no longer market some of its less nutritional options to children and said it also planned to include offerings of fruits and vegetables in many of its adult menu combinations.

articles.headline: As Some Companies Turn to Health Exchanges, G.E. Seeks a New Path
articles.snippet: Seeking to cut costs and improve care for its employees, General Electric has taken a hands-on approach with hospitals and doctors.
articles.abstract: Seeking to cut costs and improve care for its employees, General Electric has taken a hands-on approach with hospitals and doctors.
articles.lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — Although the new federal health care law is designed to help people buying individual policies, even people with employer-provided policies are beginning to see changes in their coverage as companies rethink health care for their workers, discontinuing it in a few cases and redesigning it in many others.

articles.headline: U.N. Deal on Syrian Arms Is Milestone After Years of Inertia
articles.snippet: In the most significant diplomatic initiative of the Syrian civil war, five key nations have agreed on a resolution saying Syria must give up its chemical weapons, but the statement lacks the threat of force.
articles.abstract: In the most significant diplomatic initiative of the Syrian civil war, five key nations have agreed on a resolution saying Syria must give up its chemical weapons, but the statement lacks the threat of force.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council have agreed on a resolution that will require Syria to give up its chemical weapons, but there will be no automatic penalties if the Syrians fail to comply, officials said Thursday.

articles.headline: JPMorgan Urged to Pay More in Mortgage Deal
articles.snippet: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive, met with the attorney general for nearly an hour on Thursday in Washington to discuss a deal that would involve a fine of more than $7 billion, plus $4 billion in relief for struggling homeowners.
articles.abstract: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive, met with the attorney general for nearly an hour on Thursday in Washington to discuss a deal that would involve a fine of more than $7 billion, plus $4 billion in relief for struggling homeowners.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is moving closer to striking a multibillion-dollar settlement with JPMorgan Chase over questionable mortgage practices, after authorities urged the bank to raise its offer and the bank’s chief executive took the rare step of meeting with Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. in Washington to discuss the deal.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: $300 Million in Detroit Aid, but No Bailout
articles.snippet: The Obama administration’s proposal for federal and private aid for Detroit, only a fraction of the billions the city owes, reflects President Obama’s fiscal and political limits.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration’s proposal for federal and private aid for Detroit, only a fraction of the billions the city owes, reflects President Obama’s fiscal and political limits.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two months after Detroit became the largest city ever to file for bankruptcy, top Obama administration officials will be there on Friday to propose nearly $300 million in combined federal and private aid toward a Motown comeback — only a fraction of the billions the city owes and a reflection of the budget and political limits on President Obama.

articles.headline: Shutdown Looms as Senate Passes Budget Bill
articles.snippet: After a series of Senate votes that sent the stopgap spending measure back to the House, fissures appeared in the badly divided Republican ranks.
articles.abstract: After a series of Senate votes that sent the stopgap spending measure back to the House, fissures appeared in the badly divided Republican ranks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Friday approved stopgap spending legislation to keep the federal government open without gutting President Obama’s health care law, putting new pressure on Speaker John A. Boehner to find a way out of an impasse that had the government on a steady course to a shutdown at midnight Monday.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: BlackBerry’s Future in Doubt, Keyboard Lovers Bemoan Their Own
articles.snippet: BlackBerry could soon be leaving the phone business, which is worrying its loyal users who have refused to give up its devices and their tiny buttons for touch-screen models.
articles.abstract: BlackBerry could soon be leaving the phone business, which is worrying its loyal users who have refused to give up its devices and their tiny buttons for touch-screen models.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — What is a BlackBerry user to do?

articles.headline: Have-Nots Squeezed and Stacked in Hong Kong
articles.snippet: In a city with some of the highest living costs in the world, those at the bottom of the income ladder increasingly resort to cupboardlike living spaces, a dozen or more to an apartment.
articles.abstract: In a city with some of the highest living costs in the world, those at the bottom of the income ladder increasingly resort to cupboardlike living spaces, a dozen or more to an apartment.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — On the first floor of a hulking residential building, at the end of a dimly lighted corridor, a narrow door opens up into Hong Kong’s economic underbelly.
articles.byline: By Bettina Wassener and Grace Tsoi

articles.headline: F.T.C. Votes for Inquiry Into Patent Businesses
articles.snippet: Edith Ramirez, the chairwoman of the Federal Trade Commission, said it would seek information on businesses whose main purpose was to sue other companies to collect patent royalties.
articles.abstract: Edith Ramirez, the chairwoman of the Federal Trade Commission, said it would seek information on businesses whose main purpose was to sue other companies to collect patent royalties.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stepping into a volatile debate in the technology sector, the Federal Trade Commission on Friday said it would use its subpoena power to begin an investigation of so-called patent trolls, businesses whose primary purpose is to stockpile patents and use them to sue other companies.
